title: Open the Play Store
body:
The Play Store comes installed on every Android Phone!

  • Find the Play Store icon in your Apps menu or on your screen.
  • Open the Play Store App.

title: Image of Home Screen with Play Store App

_graphic.longdescription: Image of Home Screen with Play Store App

title: Locate and Install File Manager Plus
body:
In the Play Store:

  • Search for File Manager Plus.
  • Install File Manager Plus.

title: File Manager Plus in the Play Store

_graphic.longdescription: This image shows the File Manager Plus app in the Play Store, it is already installed and fully updated, the button reads Open.

title: Update Google Drive
body:
Google Drive comes preinstalled on all Android Devices:

  • In the Play Store, search for Google Drive.
  • Tap on the Google Drive app in the menu.
  • If you see an Update Button then tap to update.

If you instead see an Open Button, as in the image, it is already fully updated.

_graphic.longdescription: Image of Google Drive app in Play Store, the button on the right reads Open so this app is fully updated.

_items.body:
Go to https://github.com/

 

If you already have a GitHub account then click in the top right to sign in (or you may already be signed in).

 

If you are new to GitHub enter your email and click Sign up for GitHub.

Enter your information.  

 

Be sure to save your password and username somewhere safe. You will need them in the future to update AAPS. 

 

You can instead use your Google or Apple account information to sign in if you prefer.

You will land in your GitHub Dashboard.  

 

This image is the old GitHub Dashboard.  At the time this training was created, there was an option to access a new GitHub dashboard which is shown below.  

 

It does not matter which dashboard you are seeing, either is fine.

This is an image of the new GitHub Dashboard to avoid confusion.

 

If this is where you were taken upon creating your account or logging in, the rest of the instructions are still the same.

title: New Component Title
body: Forking is creating your own copy of the code that is still connected to the master code for easy updates later.  This is required to build AAPS from your phone.

_items.body:
Start by accessing the main AndroidAPS repository here:

Master AAPS Repository
Click on the Fork icon that is highlighted in the red box in the image.

Scroll down and select the green Create fork button.

 

For advanced users only: Uncheck the “Copy the master branch only” box before selecting the Create fork button if you will be building developer versions or customizations.

GitHub now displays your personal AAPS Repository. You know you're looking at your code by clicking on the ... to see your username and because it shows it was forked from the main code.

Also, ensure it is fully up to date with the master code.  If it is not, you need to Sync fork.

bottom: Leave this open, you will need it shortly to add your secrets.  We will first open a new tab with the preparation file to prepare those secrets.

_previous.text: Go back to Play Store Prerequisites

_navTooltip.text: Go back to Play Store Prerequisites

title: Prior Use
body:
Do you have prior experience using AAPS?

If you answer Yes you MUST know how to find your .jks file and know its password, its alias (usually key0), and its alias password (usually the same as the JKS password).

If you do not have this information then you must answer No here.

If you answer No then you will not be able to install this build over your current build. If you are currently using AAPS and answer No, be sure to export and save your preferences from your current AAPS to a place where you will be able to access them after installing the new version.
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}}. Then select Submit Answer. Then select Continue and scroll down.

title: New Component Title
body: This is becoming very step-by-step where it is essential not to miss things or do them in the wrong order, we are moving into a process format so you do everything on one step before viewing the next.  When you have finished a step just click the right arrow above the text to move to the next step.  You can always click back a step if needed.

title: New Component Title
body: Secrets are just codes that GitHub uses to securely store your information.  The secrets prevent non-authorized users from accessing your data.  In our case, the secrets ensure that your AAPS is specific to you and can only be installed on top of another AAPS you have built for full transfer of settings.  If you have a new secret then you'll need to export your settings and import them into the new AAPS.  Keeping the same secret throughout your building ensures easy updates.  We also have a secret for accessing your Google Drive that both new and existing users must create so that GitHub can automatically save the built APK file there when we are finished building.

title: Creating your Java KeyStore (JKS) - New Users
displayTitle: Creating your Java KeyStore (JKS) - New Users
body: This set of instructions is only for users without an existing Keystore or who have forgotten the login information or lost the .jks file for their old keystore.  If you have your JKS and want to be able to install this build over your old one then you must refresh this page and select Yes in the prior question.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows over the text to move through the steps.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Download the Preparation File
_items.body:
Download the Preparation file from here:
https://github.com/nightscout/aaps-ci-preparation/releases/download/release-v1.1.2/aaps-ci-preparation.html

_items.title: Use File Manager Plus to open the Preparation File
_items.body:
1) Open the File Manager Plus app.

2) Go to Downloads.

3) Click on the Preparation File.

4) Open with your Browser.  

The file opens in a new tab in your browser.  The old tab with GitHub in it is still present.  If you are in Chrome, you will likely see a box on the top right to switch between tabs.  The number in that box reflects the number of tabs currently active in Chrome.

_items.title: Option 1: Generate JKS
_items.body: As a new user, you need a new JKS. Click the green Generate JKS button. A JKS code will appear in the lower box.

_items.title: Go to GitHub Settings
_items.body:
1) Switch Back to the GitHub tab, likely by selecting a box listing the number of active tabs in the top right corner of your browser if you are using Chrome.

2) In GitHub, select the ... near the top right and select Settings from the list.

_items.title: Access GitHub Secrets
_items.body: Select Secrets and variables from the Settings List.

_items.title: Perform Actions on GitHub Secrets
_items.body: Select Actions under Secrets and variables.

_items.title: Create a New Repository Secret
_items.body: Select the green New repository secret button.

_items.title: Copy the Name from the Preparation File
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the Preparation File browser tab.

2) Select the top blue Copy button next to KEYSTORE_SET:

_items.title: Enter the Keystore Name in GitHub
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Paste "KEYSTORE_SET" in the Name field.  To paste, long press on the box and then select paste.

_items.title: Copy the JKS from the Preparation File
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the Preparation File tab

2) Select the second blue Copy button next to the generated JKS.

_items.title: Paste the JKS code into GitHub
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Paste the JKS code into the Secret box. Use the long press to paste the code.

3) Select Add secret to save your secret.

_items.title: First Secret Success!
_items.body:
You have successfully saved your first Repository secret and can scroll down to see it in the list.

 

Scroll down to view the set of instructions to add a Google Drive Authorization secret.

title: AAPS Secrets for Current / Past Users
displayTitle: AAPS Secrets for Current / Past Users
body: This set of instructions is only for users who have a .jks from an Android Studio build to import.  You must know the keystore password, the alias, and the alias password to proceed this way.  If you follow these steps properly with the correct information you will be able to install the browser build directly over your current app without needing to export/import settings.  We ALWAYS recommend exporting the settings and saving them before any install just in case anything goes wrong.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows above the text to move through the steps.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Download the Preparation File
_items.body:
Download the Preparation file from here:
https://github.com/nightscout/aaps-ci-preparation/releases/download/release-v1.1.2/aaps-ci-preparation.html

_items.title: Open the Preparation File with File Manager Plus
_items.body:
1) Open the File Manager Plus app.

2) Go to Downloads.

3) Click on the Preparation File.

4) Open with your Browser.  

The file opens in a new tab in your browser. The old tab with GitHub in it is still present.  If you are using Chrome, will see a box on the top right to switch between tabs, the number of active tabs in your browser is displayed in the box.

_items.title: Upload Existing JKS
_items.body:
As an existing user who has built with Android Studio, you have an existing JKS. 

 

Select the Option 2 section to expand it and click on Choose File in the green bar.

_items.title: Select your JKS from your Google Drive
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the JKS stored on your device, we strongly recommend in Google Drive.  

2) Select the file.

_items.title: The JKS code appears in the Preparation File
_items.body: Verify that the JKS code has appeared in the box under the green Choose File line.

_items.title: Go to GitHub Settings
_items.body:
1) Switch Back to the GitHub tab, likely through a box listing the number of tabs in the top right corner of your browser if you are using Chrome.

2) Select the ... near the top right and select Settings from the list.

_items.title: Access GitHub Secrets
_items.body: Select Secrets and variables from the Settings list.

_items.title: Perform Actions on GitHub Secrets
_items.body: Select Actions under Secrets and variables.

_items.title: Create a New Repository Secret
_items.body: Select the green New repository secret button.

_items.title: Copy the Name from the Preparation File
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the Preparation File browser tab.

2) Select the top blue Copy button next to KEYSTORE_BASE64:

_items.title: Enter the Keystore Name in GitHub
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Paste "KEYSTORE_BASE64" in the name field.  To paste, long press on the box and then select paste.

_items.title: Copy the JKS code from the Preparation File
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the Preparation File tab

2) Select the second blue Copy button next to the imported JKS code.

_items.title: Paste the JKS code into GitHub
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Paste the JKS code into the Secret box. Use the long press to paste the code.

3) Select the green Add secret button.

_items.title: Add a second Secret for the KeyStore Password
_items.body:
Still in the GitHub tab:

1) Scroll down and select New repository secret.

_items.title: Copy the KEYSTORE_PASSWORD Name
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the Preparation File tab.

2) Select the blue Copy button next to KEYSTORE_PASSWORD:

_items.title: Save the KEYSTORE_PASSWORD secret
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Long press in the Name box and paste the copied KEYSTORE_PASSWORD name.

3) Enter the password you have for that imported KeyStore in the Secret box.

4) Select Add secret.

_items.title: Add a third Secret for the KeyStore Alias
_items.body:
Still in the GitHub tab:

1) Scroll down and select New repository secret.

_items.title: Copy the KEY_ALIAS Name
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the Preparation File tab.

2) Select the blue Copy button next to KEY_ALIAS:

_items.title: Save the KEY_ALIAS secret
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Long press in the Name box and paste the copied KEY_ALIAS name.

3) Enter the Alias you have for that KeyStore in the Secret box.  For most of us this Alias is key0.  (that is a lowercase k and 0 is a number)

4) Select Add secret.

_items.title: Add a fourth Secret for the Alias Password
_items.body:
Still in the GitHub tab:

1) Scroll down and select New repository secret.

_items.title: Copy the KEY_PASSWORD name
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the Preparation File tab.

2) Select the blue copy button next to KEY_PASSWORD:

_items.title: Save the KEY_PASSWORD secret
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the GitHub tab.

2) Long press in the Name box and paste the copied KEY_PASSWORD name.

3) Enter the password you have for that Alias in the secret box.  For most of us this password is identical to our Keystore Password.

4) Select Add secret.

_items.title: You're almost done adding Secrets!
_items.body:
You have successfully saved your Secrets and can scroll down to see all four in the list.  

 

Scroll down for a set of instructions to walk you through adding a Google Drive Authorization secret.

title: Everyone must add a Google Drive Auth secret
displayTitle: Everyone must add a Google Drive Auth secret
body: The Preparation File also helps you create a secret to authenticate your permissions to Google Drive. This is essential for GitHub to save your AAPS APK in your Google Drive once it is built.  All users, no matter which of the prior sets of instructions you followed, MUST add the Google Drive authorization to successfully use the Browser Build.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows above the text to move through the steps.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Authenticate Google Drive
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the Preparation File tab.

2) Scroll down to the Google Drive Auth section.

3) Select the green Start Auth Button.

_items.title: Select your Google Account
_items.body:
1) Select the Google Account in which you want your AAPS APK file saved.

2) Select Continue to grant access to that account.

3) The Authorization code appears in the box.

_items.title: Copy the GDRIVE_OAUTH2 Name
_items.body: Select the top blue Copy button to copy the GDRIVE_OAUTH2 Name.

_items.title: Create a new GitHub Secret
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the GitHub browser tab.

2) Scroll down to Repository secrets and select New repository secret.

(If you are a returning user you will have 4 secrets already instead of just the 1 secret shown.)

_items.title: Enter the Secret Name
_items.body: Long press in the Name box to paste the copied GDRIVE_OAUTH2 Name.

_items.title: Copy the Authorization Code
_items.body:
1) Navigate back to the Preparation File tab.

2) Click on the bottom blue Copy button to copy the code.

_items.title: Add GDrive Secret
_items.body:
1) Navigate to the GitHub tab.

2) Long press in the Secret field to paste the copied code.

3) Select the Add secret button to save the Secret.

_items.title: Verify Secret
_items.body:
Scroll down to your list of Repository secrets to verify that the GDrive_OAuth2 is saved.  

If you are a new user there are now 2 Secrets in your list.  If you are a returning user you have 5 secrets.  The pictured list has all 5 secrets for prior users.

Select the blue Continue button and then the Continue to Build AAPS button to move to the next section.

title: You've survived the hardest parts!
body: The secrets are a handful with lots of tab switching and steps and craziness.  This is where things get easy for you.  I promise if you've made it this far the building and installing will be easy.  Just stick with me through these last two sections.

title: New Component Title
body:
Our wonderful developers have done the difficult part for us here.  They've built a workflow for the system to run.  Assuming you've followed along so far and made sure you've got the most up to date code and that your Secrets are saved, this is easy.  But easy doesn't mean short.  Expect this to take about 20 minutes to build once you get it started.  You do NOT have to watch it.  It will do it without you and save the AAPS APK to your Google Drive so you can complete the last step whenever it's done.

Note: If you start this and find that you do not have the workflow to run do not panic.  You probably had an old version of the AAPS code that didn't get updated. In GitHub, go back to your Code and select Sync and sync all the newer code pieces.  Then you should be able to proceed.

title: Starting the AAPS Workflow
body:
You should be in the GitHub Tab, we are now done with the Preparation File and you will not need it again.  

In the GitHub Tab:

1) Select Actions from the bar near the top.

2) Select the arrow next to Workflows to expand all Workflows (if you don't see the workflows then your code wasn't up to date, you need to go back to the main page of your code and hit that Sync button!).

3) Under Workflows select AAPS CI.

 

4) Scroll down and select Run workflow.

title: Select the Branch and Build Variant
body:
1) Select the Branch and Build Variant you want to build.  

For most of us the Branch will be master and the Build Variant will be fullRelease.

2) Select the green Run workflow button.

title: Confirmation of Workflow run
body: There will be a message that the Workflow run was successfully requested. Most of the time this takes about 20 minutes give or take about 5 minutes. Your system will update along the way but there's no reason to watch it.  Go do something for a bit and come back in a half hour or so (or later) to do the next section.  We are done with GitHub.

_items.title: Open Google Drive
_items.body: On the phone on which you want AAPS installed, open the Google Drive application.

_items.title: Open AAPS folder
_items.body: Navigate to, or search for, the folder entitled AAPS.  Select that folder to open it.

_items.title: Open the Version Number folder
_items.body: There will be a folder entitled with the version number of the AAPS software you just built.  Select the version number folder to access the files.  In this example I have built version number 3.3.2.1

_items.title: Select the AAPS APK file to install
_items.body: Select the file with the title AAPS-<version_number>.apk to install AAPS on that phone.  In this example I am installing version 3.3.2.1 so the file I am selecting is AAPS-3.3.2.1.apk.

_items.title: Grant any required Permissions
_items.body: You phone does need permissions to install apps from Google Drive.  If you have not yet enabled those you will need to during the installation.  Select Settings from the pop-up.

_items.title: Allow installation from Google Drive
_items.body: In your settings select the slider to allow installations from the Google Drive source.

_items.title: You can now run AAPS!
_items.body:
Your AAPS build is now installed on your phone.  When installation is complete you can work through the set-up wizard described in the AAPS documentation. 


Setting Up AAPS

title: AAPS User Facebook Group
body:
Be sure to join the AAPS Users Facebook group to stay up to date on new releases and ask any questions you may have while using the system.

AAPS Users Facebook Group

title: Loop and Learn Facebook Group
body:
Loop and Learn strives to support all looping users on any system.  While the number of AAPS users is still small, it is growing and I strongly suggest you join this group as well for more questions about looping in general. 

Loop and Learn Facebook Group
